Events.RelatedDescription: Closed pull request "[Stats]Faster stats refresh" (#8478) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Small change to speed up the stats refresh since pipeline updates should allow the report to generate fast enough for this.

In theory, this will quadruple the hits on storage through this, and performance impact of this has not been analyzed.
However, I do not expect the impact of hitting 6 files 4 times instead of once every hour to be major.

This is not a critical change for functionality, and I'm happy to defer it if we so desire.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed pull request "Added LDAP support" (#6003) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Fixes #554, #5288

Since I also needed it, I added support for LDAP / Windows Active Directory. I was only able to test it within our company with our companies AD. To use it, you have to configure the `Auth.LdapUser` block in the `Web.config` file.

When `Auth.LdapUser.Enabled`, the register form is used to check the given credentials (username and password) and if the credentials are valid, it creates a new account with the username as `ldap.user` credentials instead of saving the password with `password.v3` credentials. No password credentials will be created for this account. If you want to use `LdapUser` with the current password as `LocalUser` fallback, you can just add the credentials to the account in `AuthenticationService.cs` right after the `CreateIdentity` was called (around line 252). This may be something to make configurable.

If you only want to support LDAP without regular passwords (i.e. when you are setting up a new server), I advise you to set `Auth.LocalUser.Enabled` in `Web.config` to `false`. They can coexist, since they both have an own cookie, but in most cases, you really only want to have either LDAP or local users.

Right now, there is no migration path to change existing user credentials from `password.v3` to `ldap.user`. In case the NuGet username already matches the LDAP username, the easiest way would be to update the `dbo.Credentials` entries for `password.v3` and set `Type`= `ldap.user` and `Value` = `(SELECT [Username] FROM [Users] WHERE [Key] = [UserKey])`.

**Tests are currently missing. I didn't want to put in the effort in case that it won't be merged. So I will add them, in case that there are no points speaking against merging.**

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed pull request "Add github information on the package page" (#2953) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Two node.js applications, one to look at all nuget packages, determine which have github URLs and add these to an azure queue. The second reads from the queue, and uses the github API to retrieve repo information and a rendered readme.

Instructions are provided for installing and running.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[NuGet.org Bug]: A11y_NuGet Service_Microsoft.Identity.Client_ScreenReader:When we tab to the NuGet packages' table and GitHub repositories table the screen reader is not announcing the column headers name when its read the cell data" (#9048) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Describe the bug

**Source:** https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1468943

**Actual:**
When we tab to the NuGet packages' table and GitHub repositories table and move to each cell the column header of the respective cell is not read
Similar issue is also observed in JAWS
Similar issue is observed in throughout the application

**Expected:**
Each cell should be read with its name row column number and the column header name it belongs too.

**User Impact:**
Screen readers users will face difficulty in knowing the column header reference of the cell

### Repro Steps

1. Launch the application URL: https://www.nuget.org/packages/coverlet.msbuild/
2. "Microsoft.Identity.Client" page will get open.
3. Tab to 'Used by' tab controls and press enter to select it.
4. Tab to 'NuGet packages' table.
5. Run the NVDA
6. tab to the cells of the table   

### Expected Behavior

Each cell should be read with its name row column number and the column header name it belongs too.

### Screenshots

_No response_

### Additional Context and logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[NuGet.org Bug]: A11y_NuGet Service_coverlet.msbuild_Used By-NuGet packages_DeveloperTool : Table name is not set for the 'NuGet packages' table present on the screen." (#9042) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Describe the bug

Source: https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1468937



### Repro Steps

1. Launch the application URL: https://www.nuget.org/packages/coverlet.msbuild/
2. "coverlet.msbuild" page will get open.
3. Tab to 'Used by' tab controls and press enter to select it.
4. Tab to 'NuGet packages' table.
5. Open developer tool by using ctrl+shift+c and hover over 'NuGet packages' table to check its name. 

**Actual Behavior**:

Table name is not set for the 'NuGet packages' table present on the screen.

Similar issue is observed in through out the application where ever such tables are present.

### Expected Behavior

Proper name should be set for the 'NuGet packages' table present on the screen as per the data/purpose of the table 

### Screenshots

_No response_

### Additional Context and logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[A11y] Added aria-labels to tabs on Package Details page" (#9067) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Addresses https://github.com/nuget/nugetgallery/issues/9061

**Problem:**

On the Package Details page, individual tabs do not have descriptive aria-labels that can be read by screen readers to inform users. We need to describe the purpose of the tab contents to account for cases where it may not be self-evident, like this isolated link in the Release Notes section here:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/82980589/159563014-15389a49-8469-4c09-b133-b7544a2cc896.png)

**Fix:**

To fix this, I added aria-label attributes to each of the tab content divs.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "nuget setapikey add deprecated symbol server in nuget.config" (#11686) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Do following then 
`nuget setapikey aa03d786-abcd-1001-bfdf-c4f3e8ef9bff`
See `nuget.smbsrc.net` added here, looks it's deprecated.
```
  <apikeys>
    <add key="https://www.nuget.org" value="xxxxxxxxxxxxxx" />
    <add key="https://nuget.smbsrc.net/" value="yyyyyyyyyyyy" />
  </apikeys>
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Feature]: Add support for a dedicated environment variable providing the NuGetScratch path." (#11671) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Involved

MSBuild.exe

### The Elevator Pitch

It would allow us to run multiple builds on the same CI server where:

1. Each build has its own TEMP directory pointing at the build staging directory
2. All the builds would be able to share the same NuGetScratch directory.

This way all the garbage files created by the unit tests in the temp directory are automatically deleted before the next build and all the concurrently running nuget processes can still synchronize between themselves.

### Additional Context and Details

https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/11670

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[DCR]: Align Release Label comparison to other package managers" (#11621) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Affected

NuGet.exe

### Current Behavior

Currently, Release Labels are compared case insensitive:
https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/7a5b0aafd767d105014c995378a1dbb71a5d86bd/src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.Versioning/VersionComparer.cs#L330:L331

When using for example `gitversion` to version commits and therefore NuGet packages, following scenario can appear:
* 1.0.0-alpha.1
* 1.0.0-beta.2
* 1.0.0-PullRequest.4

GitVersion creates the `PullRequest` Release Label uppercase, so that it will always be lower than `alpha` or `beta`, as following is true for most package managers: `0 < ... < 9 < A < ... < Z < a < ... < z`.
Therefore, `PullRequest` builds will correctly be considered lower than `alpha` packages.

By using `StringComparer.OrdinalIgnoreCase.Compare(version1, version2)` this advantage is taken away as `PullRequest` will be considered higher than `alpha` when compared with `OrdinalIgnoreCase.Compare`.

### Desired Behavior

NuGet should do the comparison of Release Labels the same way as other package managers are doing it:
`0 < ... < 9 < A < ... < Z < a < ... < z`.
By using [`StringComparer.Ordinal`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.stringcomparer.ordinal?view=net-6.0) the behavior would be aligned.

### Additional Context

Other tools used in development:
* [GitVersion](https://gitversion.net)
* Conan

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Feature]: Download packages via torrent" (#11603) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Involved

Other/NA

### The Elevator Pitch

This is a potential solution to [NuGet.org package size limits](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/890)

Instead of hosting the package itself, NuGet.org can give an option to host a torrent file and/or a magnet link. The client can then use a torrent library such as [MonoTorrent](https://github.com/alanmcgovern/monotorrent) to download the package.

### Additional Context and Details

_No response_
